title: Change in pH with change in HOCl

content.question:
<math alttext="H C l O aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge aqueous, plus C l O with a negative 1 charge aqueous " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HClO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>ClO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="K sub a equals 3.98 times 10 to the negative 8 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3.98</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
The acid ionization equilibrium for <math alttext="H C l O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HClO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown above. A <math alttext="0.100 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> aqueous solution of this acid has a <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of about 4.2. If a solution with an initial concentration of <math alttext="H C l O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HClO</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is allowed to reach equilibrium at the same temperature, which of the following correctly predicts its <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and why?

choices.label: The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be higher than 4.2 because increasing the concentration of the weak acid decreases the percent ionization.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be higher than 4.2 because, for weak acid solutions, the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is directly proportional to the initial concentration of the weak acid.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be lower than 4.2 because increasing the concentration of the weak acid produces more <math alttext="H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to establish equilibrium.

The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be lower than 4.2 because the <math alttext="K sub a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the weak acid is inversely proportional to the initial concentration of the weak acid.

content.answer: The <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will be lower than 4.2 because increasing the concentration of the weak acid produces more <math alttext="H 3 O with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to establish equilibrium.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
